title: 115_hr2184
content: The "Cyber Scholarship Opportunities Act of 2017" aims to address the shortage of cybersecurity professionals through the Federal Cyber Scholarship-for-Service Program. This program supports capacity building in higher education institutions and provides scholarships for students pursuing cybersecurity careers. Section 302 of the Cybersecurity Enhancement Act of 2014 is amended to include scholarship recipients pursuing an associate's degree in cybersecurity without transferring to a bachelor's program, and those with a bachelor's degree or veterans of the Armed Forces. For doctoral or master's degree recipients, agreements may include working at higher education institutions. The Cybersecurity Enhancement Act of 2014 is amended to include scholarship recipients pursuing cybersecurity degrees at higher education institutions. Recipients must demonstrate competency in relevant skills and be full-time students in eligible degree programs. The Cybersecurity Enhancement Act of 2014 now includes scholarship recipients pursuing cybersecurity degrees at higher education institutions. Recipients must be full-time or at least half-time students in eligible degree programs. The Director of the National Science Foundation will evaluate and report on the success of recruiting and retaining scholarship recipients in the public sector workforce. The Cybersecurity Enhancement Act of 2014 requires the Director of the National Science Foundation to report on student salary ranges, placement duration after graduation, retention in positions, release from obligations, remedial training needs, and determinations allowing scholarship recipients to fulfill obligations at educational institutions or in critical infrastructure positions. The Cyber Scholarship Opportunities Act of 2017 mandates regular reports to Congress by the Director of the National Science Foundation, detailing scholarship programs and job opportunities. Additionally, the Director is required to establish an online resource center for the CyberCorps community to provide updated information on cybersecurity careers and improve user experience. The Cyber Scholarship Opportunities Act of 2017 aims to enhance cybersecurity education from kindergarten to grade 12, focusing on increasing interest in cybersecurity careers, promoting safe online behavior, and improving teaching methods. Additionally, the Act seeks to improve user experience by allowing job applicants to search for positions by State, salary, and title. The Director of the National Science Foundation may grant exceptions to students for post-award employment obligations if they agree to work in critical infrastructure missions. Additionally, a pilot program will be developed to enhance critical infrastructure protection training for students pursuing careers in cybersecurity. The Director of the National Science Foundation, in coordination with the Office of Personnel Management, will assess the potential benefits of granting scholarship awards to students pursuing cybersecurity associate's degrees or industry-recognized credentials. They will also evaluate how scholarship recipients supporting the cyber workforce pipeline at educational institutions.
